title-group.article-title: Philippine School-based Toothbrushing Program Provides Daily Mass Fluoridation

body.p: We wish to complement the report by Petersen et al. (2012) on community-oriented fluoride use in Asia with an example from the Philippines, which was not included in the summary.

With the new PUFA-Index in 6- and 12-year-old children (Monse et al., 2010a), the National Oral Health Survey (Department of Education, 2008) documented a high prevalence of untreated decay and resulting dental infection. In response, the Department of Education, supported by the German Development Cooperation (GIZ), developed the Essential Health Care Program, an integrated school health program (Monse et al., 2010b), according to the principles of the Fit for School Action Framework (Benzian et al., 2012). The program addresses preventable priority diseases such as diarrhea, soil-transmitted worm infections, and caries through simple, evidence-based interventions (daily handwashing with soap and toothbrushing with fluoride toothpaste) as group activities, as well as biannual deworming. The program currently targets more than two million children throughout the Philippines. Moreover, the governments of Cambodia, Indonesia, and Laos are now adopting similar programs with support from GIZ.

The Beijing Declaration (WHO, 2007), drafted by experts convened by WHO, IADR, FDI, and CSA, states that “fluoride toothpaste remains the most widespread and significant form of fluoride used globally”. Daily group activities in a school context, focusing on skills-based education, promote healthy behavior and fluoride toothpaste use for a lifetime (Davies and Bridgman, 2011). We thus welcome the recommendation to integrate school-based prevention with general health activities, but we miss the link to a successful example of implementation on a mass scale as in the Philippines.
